questions.text: What is the most common reason for an elevated reticulocyte count among the conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Hemolytic anaemia

 

Explanation:

Hemolytic anaemia is the most common cause of elevated reticulocyte count amongst the above conditions, as it occurs due to excessive destruction of RBC while the bone marrow is still functional and it contains all the required components to produce reticulocytes. Thus, peripheral smear shows reticulocytosis.

Reticulocytosis

Reticulocytopenia

  • Acute blood loss
  • Therapeutic response to nutritional anaemia
  • Aplastic anemia
  • Nutritional anaemia
  • Iron deficiency
  • Vitamin B12 / B6 deficiency
  • Myelophthisic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndromes
  • Anaemia of chronic disease

questions.text: What is the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration (MCHC) using Hemoglobin (Hb) level is 15 g/dL and Hematocrit (Hct) is 45%?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 33.3 g/dL

 

Explanation:

  • MCHC indicates the amount of haemoglobin per unit volume.
  • In contrast to MCH, MCHC correlates the haemoglobin content with the volume of the cells.
  • It is expressed as g/dl of red blood cells or as a percentage value.

 

MCHC (g/dl) = Hb x 100/ PCV or Hematocrit

 

Given:

  • Hemoglobin (Hb) = 15 g/dL; Hematocrit (Hct) = 45%
  • Using the formula for MCHC:
  • MCHC(g/dL)=Hemoglobin (g/dL)×100/Hematocrit (%)
  • MCHC=15×100/45
  • MCHC=1500/45
  • MCHC=33.3 g/dL

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient presents for a routine check-up. His laboratory results show that his Hemoglobin (Hb) level is 14 g/dL, and his RBC count is 4.7 million cells/μL. Using these values, calculate the Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin (MCH).
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 29.8 pg

 

Explanation:

  • MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin) measures the average amount of haemoglobin per red blood cell, expressed in picograms (pg) per cell.
  • MCH provides important information about the hemoglobin content in individual red blood cells, which is crucial for diagnosing and classifying types of anemia.

MCH (pg) = Hb x 10/ RBC count

 

Given:

  • Hemoglobin (Hb) = 14 g/dL; RBC count = 4.7 million cells/μL
  • Using the formula for MCH:
  • MCH(pg)=Hemoglobin (g/dL)×10/RBC count (millions/μL)
  • MCH=14 ×10/4.7
  • MCH=140/4.7​
  • MCH=29.8 pg

questions.text: Calculate MCV in a patient where RBC count is 4.5 million cells per microliter (cells/μL), Hb 9gm/dl and Hematocrit is 30%
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 66.7 fL

 

Explanation:

  • The mean corpuscular volume (MCV) is a critical measurement to identify the underlying cause of anaemia.
  • MCV is a laboratory value that measures the average size and volume of red blood cells expressed as femtoliters (fL). It provides essential information in the diagnostic process for anaemia.
  • To calculate the MCV value, the per cent hematocrit is divided by the erythrocyte count and multiplied by 10.

 

MCV (fL) = PCV x 10/ RBC count


 

  • Given: RBC count: 4.5 million cells/μL; Hematocrit/ PCV: 40%
  • Using the formula for MCV:
  • MCV (in fL) = (Hematocrit %)×10/(RBC×1012/L)
  • MCV (fL) = Hematocrit(%)×10/RBC count(millions/μL)
  • MCV = 30×10/4.5
  • MCV = 300/4.5​
  • MCV = 66.7 fL
  • From the calculated MCV, the patient is likely to have Microcytic anaemia.

RBC indices

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b,2-c,3-d,4-a

 

Explanation:

 

RBC INDICES

DEFINITION

INTERPRETATION

MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume)

Reflects the average volume of a red blood cell and is expressed as femtoliters (fl) or cubic microns (μm³).

MCV= PCV/RBC
  • <80fl= Microcytic
  • 80-100 fl= Normocytic
  • >80= Macrocytic

MCH (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin)

Measures the average amount of haemoglobin in a single red blood cell, expressed in picograms (pg).

MCH= Hb/ RBC
  • <27 pg = Hypochromic
  • 27-32 pg = Normochromic
  • >32 pg = Hyperchromic

MCHC (Mean Corpuscular Hemoglobin Concentration)

Represents the average concentration of haemoglobin in a given volume of red blood cells, expressed as grams per deciliter (g/dl).

MCHC= MCH/MCV

Normal value: 33-37g/dl

RDW (Red Cell Distribution Width)

Indicates the variation in the size of red blood cells (Anisocytosis), expressed as a percentage.

Normal Value: 11.5-14.5%

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man presents to the clinic with fatigue, palpitations, and shortness of breath. Examination reveals pallor. Using the following values, calculate the reticulocyte production index:

 

Reticulocyte count: 5%

Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL

Hematocrit: 28%
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1.5

 

Explanation:

The reticulocyte production index (RPI) is a calculated value used to assess the bone marrow's response to anaemia by correcting the reticulocyte count for the degree of anaemia and the maturation time of reticulocytes.

 

RPI = CRC / maturation time in peripheral blood in days

 

  • CRC = Observed reticulocyte count x Patient’s haemoglobin / standard haemoglobin.
  • Reticulocyte maturation time:

 

Hematocrit

Maturation time

≥ 40%

1 Day

30-40%

1.5 Days

20-30%

2 Days

< 20%

2.5 Days

 

From the given Clinical scenario, Reticulocyte count: 5%; Hemoglobin: 9 g/dL; Hematocrit: 28%

 

  • CRC = 5 x 9 / 15 = 3.0
  • RPI = CRC / 2= 1.5

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the OPD with fatigue, weakness, and breathlessness. He shows pallor and icterus on examination. Given his hemogram results, reticulocyte count of 5%, haemoglobin of 9 g/dL, and hematocrit of 28%, calculate his corrected reticulocyte count.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 3.0

 

Explanation:

  • Normal reticulocyte count is 0.5-1.5%.
  • Corrected reticulocyte count (CRC) is the correction for the degree of anaemia, and it's calculated using the following formula.

 

CRC= Observed reticulocyte count x Patient’s haemoglobin / Standard haemoglobin

 

  • Standard hemoglobin for men= 15g/dl; for women=13g/dl
  • For the the above patient: CRC = 5 x 9 / 15 = 3.0

 

Significance of Corrected Reticulocyte Count

  • The corrected reticulocyte count is essential in evaluating anaemia to avoid misleadingly high percentages.
  • Anaemia decreases RBCs, potentially inflating the reticulocyte percentage without increased erythropoiesis.
  • The correction adjusts the reticulocyte percentage relative to the reduced RBC count, providing a more accurate assessment of bone marrow response.
  • An increased corrected reticulocyte count indicates effective erythropoiesis.
  • Low reticulocyte production may suggest bone marrow issues, iron, vitamin B12, or folate deficiencies.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Bone marrow of long bones

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman experiences ongoing fatigue and weakness, appearing pale upon examination. Laboratory investigations reveal low haemoglobin levels, and a peripheral blood smear is ordered. Which stain is most effective for visualising reticulocytes in peripheral blood smears?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) New Methylene blue

 

Explanation:

The presence of anaemia typically triggers the body's response by increasing erythropoiesis, releasing reticulocytes into circulation early as part of the compensatory mechanism to replenish red blood cells and enhance tissue oxygenation.

  • New Methylene blue is used to visualise reticulocytes in peripheral blood smears.
  • It is a supravital stain that stains living states like the RNA in reticulocytes.
  • It picks up RNA as a bluish reticulated network within erythrocytes.
  • This stain is useful in assessing bone marrow function and erythropoietic activity.

Prussian blue (Option A): Prussian blue stain detects iron in hemosiderin-containing cells. Iron is chemically reactive and turns blue-black when exposed to potassium ferrocyanide, which is present in Prussian blue.

PAS Stain (Option C): A periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) stain detects polysaccharides, such as glycogen, glycoproteins, glycolipids, and mucin in tissues.

Wright's stain (Option D): Wright’s stain is a mixture of eosin (red) and methylene blue dyes. It is used in blood smears and bone marrow aspirates to detect RBCs, WBCs, and Platelets abnormalities.

questions.text: Which stage of erythropoiesis is characterised by the expulsion of the nucleus, resulting in a smaller, pyknotic cell with increased haemoglobin content?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Reticulocytes

 

Explanation:

Reticulocytes are smaller pyknotic cells with increased haemoglobin content and have no nucleus.

  • Increased RBC production occurs as a compensatory mechanism in anaemia, initiating erythropoiesis, which is stimulated by the release of erythropoietin from the kidneys.
  • Erythropoietin prompts bone marrow to increase red blood cell production by promoting the proliferation and differentiation of hematopoietic stem cells into erythroid progenitor cells, ultimately leading to the maturation of red blood cells.

 

Stages of Erythropoiesis

  • It starts with Hematopoietic stem cells(HSC)→Common Myeloid Progenitor cells(CMP)→Proerythroblasts.

  • Once the proerythroblast has been formed, it divides multiple times, eventually forming many mature RBCs. Proerythroblast- first cell in which Hb is visualised on Electron microscopy.
  • Intermediate normoblast- first cell in which Hb is visualised on Light microscopy.
  • The first-generation cells are called basophil erythroblasts because they stain with basic dyes. Haemoglobin first appears in polychromatophilic erythroblasts and progressively increases.
  • As erythropoiesis progresses, the cell and nucleus size progressively decreases.
  • The reticulocyte is the first cell without a nucleus. During the reticulocyte stage, the cells pass from the bone marrow into the blood capillaries by diapedesis (squeezing through the pores of the capillary membrane).
  • factors affecting erythropoiesis
    • increasing- EPO, Growth hormone, T3, Cortisol, Testosterone
    • decreasing- estrogen

questions.text: Which condition is NOT typically associated with a dry tap during bone marrow aspiration?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Chronic Myeloid Leukemia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML) is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterised by the presence of the Philadelphia chromosome, resulting in the abnormal proliferation of myeloid cells.
  • The marrow in CML is hypercellular due to increased numbers of maturing granulocytic precursors (promyelocytes, myelocytes, eosinophils and basophils). A characteristic finding is the presence of scattered macrophages with abundant wrinkled, green-blue cytoplasm (sea-blue histiocytes).
  • CML can lead to increased cellularity in the bone marrow, it typically does not cause significant fibrosis or hypocellularity, the primary factor contributing to dry taps.

Causes of Dry Tap:

  • Aplastic anaemia
  • Hairy cell Leukemia
  • Myelofibrosis
  • Myelophthisic anaemia
  • AML-M7

Bone marrow biopsy (instead of BM aspiration) will be helpful in these conditions.

questions.text: If a person is 45 years old, what would be the expected percentage of cellularity in their bone marrow biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 55%

 

Explanation:

The expected percentage of cellularity in a bone marrow biopsy can be estimated using the formula:

 

% Cellularity =100 − age of the patient

 

  • So, for a 45-year-old person:
  • Cellularity = 100 − 45 = 55%
  • Therefore, the expected percentage of cellularity in their bone marrow biopsy would be 55%.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents undergoes a bone marrow biopsy, which shows a composition of cells and fat. What is the ratio of hematopoietic cells to fat cells expected in an adult?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1:1

 

Explanation:

 

  • This ratio tends to be more evenly distributed in adults, with around 50% of each cell type present. (1:1) (Option A)
  • Two primary constituents Within the bone marrow are hematopoietic and fat cells.
  • A child's marrow typically consists of 75% hematopoietic cells and 25% fat cells (3:1) (Option D), contrasting with an elderly individual's marrow, which contains approximately 25% hematopoietic and 75% fat cells (1:3). (Option B)
  • These proportions vary with age and health conditions, illustrating the dynamic nature of bone marrow composition.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presents with pancytopenia and is scheduled for a bone marrow biopsy to determine the underlying cause. What is the most common site for performing a bone marrow biopsy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Posterior Superior Iliac spine

 

Explanation:

The posterior superior iliac spine is the preferred site for obtaining bone marrow in adults because it contains the most cellular marrow, there are no vital organs in close proximity, and it is a non-weight-bearing structure.

questions.text: Identify the instrument shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Jamshidi needle

Explanation:

The Jamshidi Needle (T-shaped needle) is the most commonly used needle for bone marrow aspiration and biopsy due to its design, which allows for minimal trauma and obtaining an intact core biopsy.

 

 Salah needle (Option A): This needle is used for only bone marrow aspiration and not for biopsy.

 

 

Klima needle (Option B): The Klima needle is also used for bone marrow aspiration. It functions similarly to the Salah needle in aspirating bone marrow cells but is not the primary tool for obtaining a core biopsy

 

Quincke needle (Option D): The Quincke needle is used primarily for lumbar puncture procedures (spinal taps) to collect cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). It is not used for bone marrow biopsies.
